Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the assertion that an American coronavirus vaccine killed five Ukrainians. There is no reported testing or deaths related to this claim, and no mainstream news organizations have reported on it.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that American virologists tested residents in Ukraine using a vaccine that had not been tested on people in the United States. However, there is no evidence to support this assumption, and it is contradicted by experts who state that they are not aware of any Americans conducting COVID-19 vaccine testing in Ukraine.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no evidence or reports of testing or deaths related to an American coronavirus vaccine in Ukraine. Multiple databases and experts confirm that no COVID-19 vaccine trials are listed in Ukraine.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the impact of an American coronavirus vaccine by stating that it killed five Ukrainians without providing any evidence to support this claim.
Understate: There is no evidence to suggest that the claim understates any aspect of the situation.
Falters at times: The claim falters in providing accurate information and supporting evidence, as it is contradicted by experts and lacks sufficient support.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not provide any alternative explanation for the alleged deaths of five Ukrainians related to an American coronavirus vaccine.
